name: Carbohydrate

Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary Carbohydrates: Sugars and Starches

summary: Carbohydrates are the most common source of energy. This is becuase glucose, the simples form of carbohydrates, is the main energy fuel, not only for our cells, but for the majority of living organisms. Glucose can also be obtained from fats and protein, thus, carbohydrates are not essential for the human organism (the body can also obtain its energy requirements from ketones bodies). Carbohydrates are chains of sugar units. Based on these units, carbohydrates are classified as simple and complex. Carbohydrates are problematic, because their cause high amounts of blood glucose at once (blood glucose spike) which in term cause high amounts of insulin secretion to stabilise the glucose excess. This doesn't happen, though, with dietary fiber (complex carbohydrate), which actually slows down digestion and stabilises glucose levels, but only with simple carbohydrates (sugars). Fiber is the only essential type of carbohydrate. Also, sugars cause inflammation and lead to health problems.

functions: Collagen (bones, capillary walls, itervertebral discs, joints, ligaments, and skin)

Metabolism (ketone bodies production (ketogenesis) and fat metabolism)

summary: Vitamin B12 or Cobalamin is an essential water-soluble nutrient, hence, it cannot be stored and is easily eliminated from the body through urine or perspiration. It is part of the vitamin B-complex family and works together with the rest of the B vitamins. It is the only vitamin that contains the essential mineral Cobalt. A deficiency of any of the B vitamins disrupts the function of the entire group. Vitamin B12 is essential for energy production (metabolism), red blood cell formation, and nervous system

summary: Fatty acids or fats are lipids that serve as secondary energy supply, when glucose is absent, along with other important functions. Fatty acids are classified as unsaturated fatty acids (fluid at low temperature and unstable) and saturated fatty acids (solid at low temperature and stable). Along with industrial food processing, unsaturated fatty acids have been hydrogenized (stabilised) to increase the shelf life in food stores, turning them into trans-unsaturated fats, which damage our health and leading to genetic mutations of our DNA and, thus, disease. Omega-3 fatty acids (alpha-linoleic acid (ALA), docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA)) and omega-6 fatty acids (linoleic acid) are the only essential fatty acids. Fatty acids are essential for cardiovascular system (blood vessels), cell membranes, nutrient absorption, endocrine system (hormone production), energy production and storage (metabolism), immune system, and nervous system (neurotransmitter production). Excess amounts of omega-6 fatty acids cause inflammation and lead to health problems. Be careful to keep a 2:1 intake ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids, that is, for every gram of omega-3 fatty acids, you should not exceed 2 grams of omega-6 fatty acids.

functions: Cardiovascular system (blood glucose and cholesterol balance)
name: Dietary fiber

summary: Dietary fiber or roughage is the part from plant foods that we are unable to digest and absorb. It passes through the digestive tract, slowing down digestion. This causes satiety, improved digestion, an increased nutrient absorption, stable glucose and insulin levels, and thus stable cholesterol levels. Fiber can also ferment in the colon, thus, improving the bacterial enzyme (gut flora) health. It is thus essential for digestive system, immunse system, and cardiovascular system

name: Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

summary: Vitamin B9, Folic acid or Folate is an essential water-soluble nutrient, hence, it cannot be stored and is easily eliminated from the body through urine or perspiration. It is part of the vitamin B-complex family and works together with the rest of the B vitamins. A deficiency of any of the B vitamins disrupts the function of the entire group. As it name suggests ('foliage'), vitamin B9 is found in leafy vegetables. Vitamin B9 is essential for protein metabolism, red blood cell production, and for growth and development, especially during pregnancy

Vitamin B3 is essential for energy production (metabolism), steroid production and redox reactions such as cellular respiration, electron transfer between molecules, muscle relaxation, and protection against free radicals (Reactive oxygen species or ROS) that cause oxidative stress (cellular damage that leads to aging, DNA mutations, inflammation, and others). Growth and development (cholesterol and protein production)

Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Minerals: Selenium
University of Maryland Medical Center, Complementary and Alternative Medicine Guide, Selenium

summary: Selenium (Se) is an essential trace element. It is essential for antioxidant protection against oxidative stress and triiodothyronine (T3) thyroid hormones production, which are involved in all metabolisc functions (bones, cardiovascular system, central nervous system (arousal, attention, learning, memory, mood, reward system), cholesterol production, energy production, gene expression, growth and development, muscular system, protein production, reproduction)

functions: Collagen (bones, capillary walls, itervertebral discs, joints, ligaments, and skin)
Nervous system (neurotransmitter production involved in arousal, attention, learning, memory, mood, muscle contraction, reward system, and senses)
name: Protein (Amino acids)

references.credit: Right Diagnosis, Symptoms of Protein deficiency
Beth Asaff Cook, Lovetoknow, Protein Deficiency Symptoms
The world's healthiest foods, Amino acids
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Protein Functions
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Protein and Amino acids

summary: Protein is the third most important nutrient, after oxygen and water, being the main functional and structural component of all cells. Proteins are chains of amino acids and amino acids are the building blocks of all life forms. There are 20 amino acids, from which only 10 are essential (Arginine, Histidine, Isoleucine, Leucine, Lysine, Methionine, Phenylalanine, Threonine, Tryptophan, Valine). Protein quality of food varies, according to the essential amino acid content. Protein with all essential amino acids is complete, the rest is incomplete. Thus, it is important to focus on complete protein foods. Because of their importance, amino acids and protein are essential for the majority of body functions (cell structure and signaling, endocrine system (hormone production), gene expression (DNA and RNA production), growth and developmnet, metabolism (enzyme production), collagen production (bones, capillary walls, itervertebral discs, joints, ligaments, and skin), immune system (antibody production), cardiovascular system (blood cell production), nervous system (neurotransmitter production involved in arousal, attention, learning, memory, mood, muscle contraction, reward system, and senses)

deficiencies: Cracks or sores at corners of mouthand eyes
functions: Central nervous system (arousal, attention, learning, memory, mood, reward system)
Metabolism (amino acid metabolism and production (cysteine, methionine, serine, tryptophan), glycogen to glucose convertion (glycogenolysis), choline and niacin production and metabolism)
Muscular system (magnesium, potassium, and sodium metabolism)
name: Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

references.credit: The world's healthiest foods, Vitamin B6
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Vitamins and Minerals, Vitamin B6
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Vitamins: Vitamin B6 -- Pyridoxine

summary: Vitamin B6 or Pyridoxine is an essential water-soluble nutrient, hence, it cannot be stored and is easily eliminated from the body through urine or perspiration. It is part of the vitamin B-complex family and works together with the rest of the B vitamins. A deficiency of any of the B vitamins disrupts the function of the entire group. Vitamin B6 is essential for amino acid metabolism, cardiovascular system (hemoglobin production), immune system (histamine production), central nervous system (arousal, attention, learning, memory, mood, reward system), muscular system (magnesium, potassium, and sodium metabolism), and gene expression (DNA and RNA production)

name: Sugars

references.credit: Mercola, Exercise and Diet Combat Inflammation, Allowing You to Live Longer
Dr. David M. Marquis, DC, DACBN, Mercola, How Inflammation Affects Every Aspect of Your Health
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Carbohydrates
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary Carbohydrates: Sugars and Starches

summary: Sugars are carbohydrates with only one (monosaccharides) and two (disaccharides) sugar units, hence the term simple carbohydrates. Sugars bring no benefits to our body, on the contrary, they damage our body. Sugars are rapidly absorbed and cause blood glucose spikes and high insulin secretion. Natural sugars from fruits and vegetables come along with fiber which slows down absorption. The real problem comes from refined sugars (sweeteners), which cause inflammation within our digestive system and cardiovascular system leading to health problems. They are found in all processed foods and desserts. Reduce sugars to less than 5% of daily energy intake.

name: Trans-unsaturated fatty acid (Trans-fat)

references.credit: Mercola, Exercise and Diet Combat Inflammation, Allowing You to Live Longer
Dr. David M. Marquis, DC, DACBN, Mercola, How Inflammation Affects Every Aspect of Your Health
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Fats, Lipids And Oils
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary fat: Total fat and Fatty acids

summary: Trans-unsaturated fatty acids or, simply, trans fat are unsaturated fatty acids that have been hydrogenized (stabilised) during food processing to increase their shelf life for commercial purposes. They are found in all processed food and margarine. Trans fat cause inflammation. Long-term inflammation leads to chronic inflammation, that is, the immune system goes mad and triggers inflammation and immune reponses although there is no threat (it thinks it is something normal to do). This behaviour is an autoimmune problem caused by DNA damage and mutation. Chronic inflammation is the root cause of all diseases. Inflammation can be determined more precisely using a C-reactive protein (CRP) test. Eliminate trans fat found in processed food completely for the sake of your health and wellness.

functions: Cardiovascular system (blood vessels health and heart muscle tone)
Central nervous system (arousal, attention, learning, memory, mood, reward system)
Digestive system (intestine and stomach muscle tone)
Fatty acid, sterol, and acetylcholine production
Peripheral nervous system (neuromuscular junctions involved in muscle contraction and senses)
name: Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

references.credit: The world's healthiest foods, Vitamin B1 - Thiamin
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Vitamins and Minerals, Thiamine
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Vitamins: Vitamin B1 -- Thiamine

summary: Vitamin B1 or Thiamine is an essential water-soluble nutrient, hence, it cannot be stored and is easily eliminated from the body through urine or perspiration. It is part of the vitamin B-complex family and works together with the rest of the B vitamins. A deficiency of any of the B vitamins disrupts the function of the entire group. Vitamin B1 is essential for energy production (metabolism), neuromuscular juctions involved in all muscular activities (heart, intestines, skeletal muscles, stomach, etc.), and mental arousal (alertness, attention, learning, memory, mood, rewards system etc.)

functions: Electrolyte (acid/base (pH) balance, fluid balance (osmotic pressure), muscle tone, and nerve function)
name: Sodium (N)

summary: Sodium (N) is an essential mineral element. It is essential for electrolyte activity (acid/base (pH) balance, fluid balance (osmotic pressure), muscle tone, and nerve function)

functions: Epithelial cells (bladder, eyes, intestines, lungs, nose, skin, stomach, throat, urinary tract, vagina)
name: Vitamin A

references.credit: Healthline, What's Causing This Eye Condition?
The world's healthiest foods, Vitamin A
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Vitamins and Minerals, Vitamin A
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Vitamins: Vitamin A -- Betacarotene
National Institutes of Health, Vitamin A
University of Maryland Medical Center, Complementary and Alternative Medicine Guide, Vitamin A (Retinol)

summary: Vitamin A is an essential fat-soluble nutrient, hence, it requires fat to be absorbed and can be deposited within tissues. Vitamin A is composed of retinoids (retinol, retinal, retinoic acid) and carotenoids (beta-carotene). As their names suggest, retinoids are essential for retina (eyes), especially for the development of rods (night vision). Vitamin A is also essential for oxidative stress protection (antioxidant), immune system, epithelial cells (bladder, eyes, intestines, lungs, nose, skin, stomach, throat, urinary tract, vagina), and growth and development (bones and teeth)

functions: Collagen (bones, capillary walls, itervertebral discs, joints, ligaments, and skin)
Metabolism (tryptophan to serotonin convertion, tyrosine to epinephrine and norepinephrine convertion, Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) to tetrahydrofolic acid convertion)

When you say 'C', think about Colds and Collagen, because it is essential for collagen production (connective tissue found in bones, capillary walls, itervertebral discs, joints, ligaments, and skin), immune system, and oxidative stress protection (antioxidant)

name: Zinc (Zn)

references.credit: Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Vitamins and Minerals, Zinc
Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Minerals: Zinc
University of Maryland Medical Center, Complementary and Alternative Medicine Guide, Zinc

summary: Zinc (Zn) is an essential trace element. It is essential for growth and development, especially during pregnancy, healing and regeneration (collagen production), fertility, immune system, metabolism, detoxification, and redox reactions such as cellular respiration and protection against free radicals (Reactive oxygen species or ROS) that cause oxidative stress (cellular damage that leads to aging, DNA mutations, inflammation, and others)
